thread.title: Schneiderman Is Out and the Jockeying to Replace Him Has Begun

author: Mike Vilensky
title: Schneiderman Is Out and the Jockeying to Replace Him Has Begun
text:
19 COMMENTS Eric Schneiderman’s resignation as New York attorney general set off quick jockeying on Tuesday for his job—one of the most powerful positions in the state, and a role that wasn’t expected to change hands this year.
The process for replacing the two-term attorney general, who had been expected to win re-election in November, got off to a chaotic start: An array of New York Democrats threw their hats in the ring and lawmakers competed to influence the process. The person who is named by the state Legislature as a replacement would have to run in November to keep the post.
Mr. Schneiderman, a Democrat, resigned hours after the New Yorker magazine published an article in which four women accused the 63-year-old of physically assaulting them. Mr. Schneiderman said in a statement that he had “engaged in role-playing” in intimate relationships but had never engaged in nonconsensual sex .

Attorney General’s Tenure “This week should be an important reminder of why we need more women in leadership positions,” said Assemblywoman Nily Rozic, a Queens Democrat. “I’m sure a number of qualified candidates will be stepping forward.”
Under state law, the New York solicitor general, Barbara Underwood, will serve as the acting attorney general until the Legislature chooses a replacement.
Ms. Underwood, 73, is New York’s first female attorney general. She has been solicitor general since January 2007. She was first appointed by Gov. Andrew Cuomo when he was attorney general, and reappointed by Mr. Schneiderman.
A Georgetown University Law School graduate, she previously worked as an assistant prosecutor for the Brooklyn U.S. attorney’s office and a trial attorney for the Manhattan district attorney’s office, arguing 20 cases before the U.S. Supreme Court, according to the attorney general’s office.
“I am honored to serve the people of New York as acting Attorney General,” Ms. Underwood said in a statement. She said the office’s work “continues without interruption.”
New York City Public Advocate Letitia James is among the Democrats being mentioned as potential candidates for the attorney general job. Photo: Erik Mcgregor/Pacific Press/ZUMA Press Mr. Cuomo is pushing New York City Public Advocate Letitia James for attorney general, among other contenders, according people close to the governor. The governor was among the earliest Democrats to call for Mr. Schneiderman’s resignation Monday night.
On Tuesday, Mr. Cuomo said “a qualified woman would be great, especially in this time.”
Another name that has become a frequent mention in political circles in the hours since Mr. Schneiderman said he would exit: Preet Bharara , the former Manhattan U.S. attorney who prosecuted some of Albany’s biggest public-corruption cases in recent years.
New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, who stayed silent on Monday night when other Democratic leaders called for Mr. Schneiderman’s resignation, said the allegations in the New Yorker article were “horrifying,” but declined to name his preferred candidate.
U.S. Rep. Kathleen Rice is considering running for attorney general, a person close to her said. Photo: Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call/Newscom/ZUMA Press Queens Sen. Michael Gianaris is another possible contender. Photo: Sachelle Babbar/ZUMA Press In Albany, legislators were privately discussing the issue and reviewing the logistical rules as they prepare to vote on Mr. Schneiderman’s successor. They are expected to take up the issue in the coming days.
Republicans control the state Senate, while Democrats run the Assembly. The Assembly Democratic caucus holds the cards in a joint legislative vote because they have by far the most members of any legislative group. In the past, that Assembly caucus has elevated one of their own when tasked with filling a statewide job due to an abrupt resignation. In 1993, Assembly members voted in fellow legislator Oliver Koppell as attorney general after Robert Abrams resigned to join a law firm.
Assembly Speaker Carl Heastie, a Bronx Democrat, has said little so far, telling reporters in Albany on Tuesday morning that he plans to take up the issue soon and didn’t rule out a candidate from outside his chamber.
Ms. James, a Democrat who won re-election as public advocate last year, is among the candidates under discussion by Democratic lawmakers, according to people involved in the talks. A 59-year-old lawyer, she would be the first African-American attorney general of New York. She declined Tuesday to say if she wanted the job, telling reporters: “The next attorney general will be decided by the state Legislature, and I await their decision.”
Other Democrats around the state have expressed interest, both as the legislative pick or in running their own campaigns. Among them are U.S. Rep. Kathleen Rice, the former Nassau County district attorney, Queens Sen. Michael Gianaris, and former gubernatorial candidate Zephyr Teachout.
Ms. Teachout wrote on Twitter that she is “seriously considering” running. A person close to Ms. Rice said she is considering running, as did a Gianaris spokesman about Mr. Gianaris.
Zephyr Teachout said on Twitter she is ‘seriously considering’ running for New York Attorney General. Photo: Mike Groll/Associated Press Another person who has been approached by Democratic officials to weigh a possible run is Ben Lawsky, the former superintendent of the state Department of Financial Services and a former federal prosecutor in the Manhattan U.S. attorney’s office, according to a person familiar with the matter.
Mr. Lawsky also was Mr. Cuomo’s chief of staff during his first term in the governor’s office.
On the Republican side, lawyer Manny Alicandro is running for the nomination to be attorney general.
Democrats have a more than 2-to-1 voter enrollment advantage statewide, but Republicans were pointing to the Schneiderman scandal to boost their candidate.
A bipartisan legislative resolution passed before the allegations against Mr. Schneiderman surfaced declared May 8 “Domestic Violence and Prevention Day in the State of New York.”
—Erica Orden, Melanie Grayce West and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
contributed to this article.
